#Text=West Kootenays
#Text=The West Kootenays is south-eastern British Columbia , Canada .

#Text=The area is approximately defined as being the area south of the Trans Canada Highway ( Hwy # 1 ) from Revelstoke and including the valleys of Slocan Lake and Kootenay Lake and at least part of the Arrow Lake valley ( Columbia River ) , as far south as the USA border .
#Text=Cities , towns and villages
#Text=is " the Queen City " of the Kootenays , renowned for its tourism , culture and outdoor activities .
#Text=is the crossroads of the Kootenays .
#Text=Whether you decide to stop here or not , you will likely pass through it if you visit the West Kootenays
#Text=is an industrial town dominated by one of the largest lead-zinc smelters in the world
#Text=is a medium-sized town on the east side of Arrow Lakes ( Columbia River ) .
#Text=is a small village on Slocan Lake , about 45 minutes drive east of Kaslo .
#Text=is a picturesque mountain town world famous for its skiing at Red Mountain Resort and also noted for great mountain biking .
#Text=is a small town near the US border , a convenient food and fuel stop on the Crowsnest Pass Highway .
#Text=is an attractive village on the west shore of Kootenay Lake , nestled between the Purcell Mountains and Selkirk Mountains and home to the world 's oldest intact sternwheeler , the SS Moyie .
#Text=is a village equidistant from Nelson , Castlegar , and Trail , known as " the Hub of the Kootenays " .
#Text=is at the south end of Kootenay Lake next to some of the best of the limited agricultural areas around this region .
#Text=is the eastern terminal of the Arrow Lake ferry , connecting Highway 6 with Needles on the western shore .
#Text=Understand
#Text=In general , the West Kootenays is a little more remote and a little more difficult to get into and travel around than some of the more populated parts of the province .
#Text=You will probably find that the residents of this area live here at least partly because that 's what they like .
#Text=Winding roads require somewhat slower travel .
#Text=If locals have one complaint , especially during tourist season , it 's about visitors roaring about , making excessive noise and generally making the highways unsafe and unpleasant .
#Text=To fully appreciate the place , visitors need to slow down , relax and enjoy what the region has to offer .
#Text=There 's little interest in seeing the frantic bustle of the big city imported here by visitors in too much of a hurry .
#Text=The West Kootenays does n't include the Columbia River and Kootenay River Valley south of Golden to Cranbrook .
#Text=This is the East Kootenays .
#Text=It 's very nice , but it 's not the West Kootenays .
#Text=Talk
#Text=You may hear the phrase Kootenay Time used occasionally .
#Text=This may be interpreted as " I 'll get there when I get there " or " It will happen when it happens " .
#Text=You may find some shops that are n't always open right on time .
#Text=Relax .
#Text=It 's not usually a crisis .
#Text=The ubiquitous FSR .
#Text=This is a Forest Service Road or , more commonly , a logging road , which is what these roads were built to service .
#Text=They are often identified by brown Forest Service signs , they seem to be everywhere and they are the only real access into the backcountry .
#Text=Many are rough and steep and require high clearance vehicles .
#Text=Maybe a vehicle that does n't have a paint job you 're unusually fond of .
#Text=If there is active logging going on , you may also meet large trucks with loads of logs .
#Text=You can get lost or stuck .
#Text=Caution is advised .
#Text=Get in
#Text=By plane - the only airport served by a major carrier is in Castlegar .
#Text=Air Canada Express is the only major airline available with flights to Vancouver , the Okanagan and Calgary .
#Text=There is a smaller airstrip near Trail which has a commercial operation connecting to Vancouver .
#Text=Private planes could also land at strips in Kaslo , Nelson and Creston .
#Text=By road - by heading south from Revelstoke towards Nakusp or from Hwy 3 through Creston or Trail .
#Text=By bus - possible but slow and not very convenient .
#Text=Get around
#Text=The easiest way to see the Kootenays is by private vehicle .
#Text=There is very limited public transit in this region .
#Text=Some routes are pretty quiet so hitch-hiking could be chancy , especially late in the day and outside the main tourist season .
#Text=In the summer , it 's a popular destination for motorcyclists .
#Text=Some hardier types will enjoy biking in the area , just be aware that the hills will give you a good workout .
#Text=BC Transit operates the West Kooteney Transit System which runs within and between many towns .
#Text=See
#Text=The area generally has quite stunning scenery .
#Text=Details are contained in the listings for many of the towns in the region .
#Text=Do
#Text=There are many reasons to visit ( or live in ) the West Kootenays .
#Text=The longer one stays , the more opportunities appear .

#Text=In addition to the most noticeable such as the various Provincial Parks , towns and local ski hills , there are many backcountry trails which really expose you to some of the wilderness that remains in this part of the province .
#Text=There is a trails guidebook which is a good start , but repeated visits and contact with the locals can get you into some quite amazing destinations .
#Text=Accessing many of these areas often requires a high-clearance vehicle , travel on logging roads and good maps , just to sort out where to go .
#Text=Eat
#Text=If all you want is the usual fast food , the West Kootenays has the usual complement of fast food outlets , but it is possible to do better than that .
#Text=All of the communities in the region have at least a few good to excellent establishments serving a pretty wide selection of food .

#Text=There is n't really a regional cuisine but many of the establishments cater to vegetarians and to omnivores , many take the trouble to source locally-grown produce and some have created some pretty unique menu items .
#Text=Drink
#Text=There are at least 3 brewing companies in the West Kootenays :
#Text=In Creston there is the Columbia Brewing Company , in Revelstoke there is the Mt Begbie Brewing Company and in Nelson there is the Nelson Brewing Company , advertising organic ales .
#Text=Given this choice , make it a point to sample some of the local brews while travelling in the region .
#Text=The region is n't well known for wineries ; there just is n't the heat or the soil available here the way there is in the Okanagan .
#Text=However , despite that , there are at least two wineries in the region : Columbia Gardens Vineyard & Winery just south of Trail and Skimmerhorn Winery & Vineyard in Creston .
